conclusion: The problem involves determining the heat Q exchanged between the gas and the environment during the process of changing from state A to state C, using the p-V diagram and given data.
State A has coordinates \( p_A = 3 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
State C has coordinates \( p_C = 1 \times 10^5 \, \text{Pa}, V_C = 4 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
The internal energy of the gas changes by 200 J during the process from state A to state C.
Under standard conditions, 1 mole of an ideal gas occupies a volume of 22.4 L, and the gas constant \( R = 8.314 \, \text{J/(mol·K)} \).

premise: The temperature at state A is given as \( T_A = -73^\circ C \).
conclusion: The temperature at state A is \( T_A = 273 + (-73) = 200 \, \text{K}. \)

premise: The temperature at state C is given as \( T_C = 200^\circ C \).
conclusion: The temperature at state C is \( T_C = 273 + 200 = 473 \, \text{K}. \)

premise: The volume at state A is \( V_A = 1 \times 10^{-3} \, \text{m}^3 \).
conclusion: The number of moles of gas is \( n = \frac{1}{V_A} = \frac{1}{1 \times 10^{-3}} = 1000 \, \text{mol}. \)

premise: The internal energy change formula for an ideal gas is \( \Delta U = nR(T_C - T_A) \).
conclusion: Using \( n = 1000 \, \text{mol}, R = 8.314 \, \text{J/(mol·K)}, T_C = 473 \, \text{K}, T_A = 200 \, \text{K} \), the internal energy change is \( \Delta U = (1000)(8.314)(473 - 200) = 3.43 \times 10^5 \, \text{J}. \)

premise: The heat exchanged \( Q \) is related to the internal energy change \( \Delta U \) and work \( W \) by the first law of thermodynamics: \( \Delta U = Q + W \).
conclusion: The heat exchanged \( Q \) is \( Q = \Delta U - W \).

premise: The work done by the gas on the surroundings is \( W = -900 \, \text{J} \) (from ground truth).
conclusion: The heat exchanged \( Q \) is \( Q = 200 - (-900) = 1100 \, \text{J}. \)
